title.narrative: Improving the Psychosocial Well-being of Migrants

description.narrative: Title : Improving the Psychosocial Well-being of Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Kassala Start and end dates: 01/01/2019 31/03/2019 Pcode: P7877 Summary: This project builds on the work of SRCS in the Kassala Safe House through a separate project which targets different locations in Kassala reception centres for asylum seekers refugee camps and a centre for unaccompanied children. The goal of the project is the enhanced well being and dignity of asylum seekers and refugees in the reception centres and camps in Kassala State. Outcomes; SRCS staff and volunteers have improved capacity to provide quality PS services in a supportive working environment in the camps and reception centres in Kassala Children and young people in camps in Kassala have been provided with needs-based timely PS services in a respectful manner The wellbeing and dignity of the most vulnerable asylum seekers and refugees (including survivors of SGBV and trafficking people with disabilities and the elderly ) in refugee camps and reception centres in Kassala is strengthened Location: Kassala Sudan Beneficiaries: NA Donor: BRC GF and Disaster Risk Alliance (20k scale-up) PNSs/Partners: Danish Red Cross Sudanese Red Crescent Budget: 200 000 (GF) & 20 000 scale-up (RF) Current situation (Jan 2020): due to a slow start to project activities in 2019 because of political instability in Sudan there was a no-cost extension to keep the project running until the end of March 2020. An extra 20 000 RF was also made available at the end of 2020 which will focus on creating child-friendly spaces in the camps where the project operates. DRC & SRCS will focus on strengthening their response to refugee and migrant children especially separated and unaccompanied children at border reception points through the provision of child friendly spaces and training of frontline staff and volunteers working at the border reception points. Staff and volunteers will be better equipped and appropriately trained and know how to identify refer and be sensitive to needs of children especially unaccompanied and separated children.
